questions.question:
Question 1: A pregnant female arrives at your hospital for her antenatal check-up. As an intern, you were 
required to draw her family pedigree chart while taking history. She has previously delivered 
full-term healthy dizygotic twins 5 years back. Which of the following symbol will you use to 
denote dizygotic twins in a pedigree chart?
questions.explanation:
Pedigree charts are graphical representations of a person's family tree and are useful for 
identifying the pattern of inheritance of genetic disorders. Thus, they are vital in the 
history-taking of patients, especially in pregnancy. Option B is the symbol denoting dizygotic 
twins in a pedigree chart. Option A denotes monozygotic twins in the pedigree chart. Option C denotes offsprings. Option D denotes consanguineous marriage.

questions.question:
Question 2: Which pattern of inheritance does the pedigree chart denote? 181 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The above pedigree chart denotes an autosomal recessive pattern. In the above pedigree chart, 
both males and females are carriers (equally affected) which indicates an autosomal pattern. 
Parents are unaffected (both are carriers/heterozygotes), and no affected members in other 
generations. 25% of the children are normal, 50% are carriers, and only 25% are affected. This 
indicates a a recessive pattern. Pedigree charts in various modes of inheritance: 193 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: While volunteering at the blood donation camp, Ananya came across a case of a thalassemic 
infant who has an AB-positive blood group. Her father is B-positive and her mother is 
A-positive. In order to understand more about donor eligibility to explain the concerned 
parents, she wishes to understand the inheritance pattern of ABO blood grouping. Can you 
help her out by choosing the correct option?
questions.explanation:
The inheritance pattern of the ABO blood grouping system is codominance. Codominance: Gene expression and mendelian traits are usually described as dominant or recessive; in some 
cases, both of the alleles of a gene pair contribute to the phenotype—a condition called 
codominance. Examples include histocompatibility and ABO blood group antigens. Classification of genetic disorders Mendelian disorders (Classic inheritance) • Autosomal dominant • Autosomal recessive • X-linked dominant • X-linked recessive Non-mendelian disorders ( Non-classic inheritance) • Trinucleotide repeat mutations • Fragile X syndrome • Friedreich ataxia • Huntington’s disease • Mutations in mitochondrial genes: MELAS, MERRF • Genomic imprinting • Angelman syndrome • Prader–Willi syndrome • Silver–Russell syndrome • Gonadal mosaicism Chromosomal disorders: • Microdeletions: Cri du chat syndrome • Down’s syndrome, Turner’s syndrome, Klinefelter’s syndrome

questions.question:
Question 4: An MBBS student, after attending a class on genetic disorders, noticed that a particular 
disorder appears in three consecutive generations of his family without any sex predilection. 
While drawing his pedigree chart, it also struck him that phenotypically normal family 
members were having healthy offspring. Based on this information, he concluded the pattern 
of inheritance of this disorder. What is the correct pattern? 182 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The pattern of inheritance in this genetic disorder is autosomal dominant. Points in favour: • Autosomal dominant disorders have a vertical mode of transmission (individuals of two 
generations are affected—parent and children affected). 194 
Sold by @itachibot • It appears in three consecutive generations of a family without any sex predilection. • An affected individual has a 50% chance of passing on the deleterious gene in each pregnancy. • Males and females are equally affected. • Unaffected individuals do not pass on the disorder to their children.

questions.question:
Question 5: A young boy presented with a history of a genetic disorder. On further enquiry, his father and 
grandmother had the same disease as well. Prior to his birth, the doctor had counseled the 
father that there is a 50% chance of passing the deleterious gene to his offspring irrespective 
of sex. Which of the following diseases is an example of this inheritance pattern?
questions.explanation:
Autosomal dominance is the inheritance pattern seen in his question due to three-generation of 
affected family members with a 50% chance of passing the deleterious gene to the next generation 
irrespective of sex. Tuberous sclerosis is an example of an autosomal dominant (AD) disorder. Note: • All Ehlers–Danlos syndrome types are autosomal dominant, except types V, VI, and VII. • All types of osteogenesis imperfecta are autosomal dominant, except types II, III, and VII.

questions.question:
Question 6: Aryan is the first child born to parents suffering from achondroplasia. Although he is not 
suffering from this condition, the parents wish to know the chances of developing 
achondroplasia in the second child. What is the correct response?
questions.explanation:
The chances of having an affected baby when both parents have achondroplasia 
(autosomal-dominant disorder) is 75%. • Autosomal dominant (AD) disorders are manifested in the heterozygous state. • If both of the parents are affected, the chances of having an affected baby are 75% (50% - 'Aa', 
and 25% - 'AA'). Note: Here, we consider both parents as 'Aa' (heterozygous) because 'AA' (homozygous) is usually fatal 
in the first few months of life. The odds of having an affected baby does not change with 195 
Sold by @itachibot subsequent pregnancies.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 3-year-old boy presented with short stature and delayed motor milestones. An x-ray showed 
a trident hand as given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 183 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The x-ray shows short stubby fingers, with a separation between middle and ring fingers. This is 
called a trident hand and is seen in achondroplasia. Achondroplasia It is an autosomal-dominant chondrodysplasia and the most common condition characterized by 
disproportionate short stature. It is caused by mutations in the gene coding for fibroblast growth 
factor receptor type 3 (FGFR3). Clinical features (see image below): Short stature, extreme joint laxity, bowing of legs, macrocephaly, frontal bossing, midfacial 
hypoplasia, small chest, redundant skin folds, recurrent infections, cor pulmonale, and restrictive 
pulmonary disease 196 
Sold by @itachibot Radiological features • Champagne glass pelvic inlet • Trident hand • Shortening of tubular bones with metaphyseal flaring. • Chevron deformity

questions.question:
Question 8: A 14-year-old child presented with multiple hyperpigmented lesions of around size 15-20 mm 
in the trunk and extremities. Similar lesions of size 2-3 mm were found in his axillary and 
inguinal regions. A photograph of his eye showing a characteristic lesion is shown below. 
What is the likely diagnosis? 184 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The features of cafe-au-lait macules, axillary and inguinal freckling along with Lisch nodules 
points toward a diagnosis of neurofibromatosis-1 (NF-1). The multiple hyperpigmented lesions of more than 15 in the trunk and extremities are known as 
cafe-au-lait macules (>5mm in prepubertal, >15mm in postpubertal) and are present in 
100% of NF1 cases. The lesions of around 2-3mm in the axillary and inguinal regions are known 
as axillary/inguinal freckling and are pathognomonic of NF1. The given image shows discrete 
nodules over the iris, which are referred to as Lisch nodules, and are commonly seen in patients 
with NF-1. Lisch nodules are iris hamartomas. Neurofibromatosis: It is an autosomal-dominant neurocutaneous syndrome with the following

questions.question: Question 9: Which one of the following is not included in the criteria for neurofibromatosis 1?

options.c: Dysplasia of the sphenoidal and tibial bone

questions.explanation:
In neurofibromatosis 1 (NF1), two or more of the following clinical manifestations are present: • Six or more café-au-lait macules • Axillary or inguinal freckling • Two or more iris Lisch nodules (hamartomas of iris) • Two or more neurofibromas or 1 plexiform neurofibroma • A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoidal and tibial bone dysplasia • Optic gliomas 198 
Sold by @itachibot • A 1st-degree relative with NF-1

questions.question:
Question 10: Consider the following statements about café- au- lait macules associated with 
neurofibromas:

options.a: Statements A, C and E true, B and D false
options.b: Statements B and C true, A, D and E false
options.c: Statements B, D and E true, A and C false
options.d: Statements A and B true, C, D and E false

questions.explanation:
Statement C: The spots are scattered over the body surface, with a predilection for the trunk and 
extremities; sparing the face. Statement D: For diagnosis, the macules should be >5 mm in prepubertal and >15 mm in 
postpubertal individuals. Statement E: 6 or more spots should be present for the clinical diagnosis of neurofibromatosis Café-au-lait macules: • Hallmark of neurofibromatosis, present in around 100% of the patients. • 6 or more café-au-lait spots should be present for the clinical diagnosis of neurofibromatosis 
along with other criteria. • Present at birth, but increase in size, number, and pigmentation, especially during the first few 
years of life. Note: Other diseases associated with multiple café-au-lait spots: Ataxia telangiectasia, Bloom syndrome, 
Fanconi's anaemia, McCune–Albright syndrome, tuberous sclerosis, Maffucci syndrome, Hunter 
syndrome. Other neurocutaneous syndromes: • Sturge–Weber syndrome: port-wine stain over the trigeminal distribution, contralateral 
hemiparesis, focal seizures contralateral to the side of facial capillary malformations, calcification 
of the cerebral cortex, mental retardation, and congenital glaucoma • von Hippel–Lindau disease: retinal angiomas; cerebellar and spinal hemangioblastomas • Ataxia telangiectasia • Tuberous sclerosis Café-au-lait spots are shown in the image given below: 199 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: A 9-month-old child presents with a history of a condition seen in the image below. On 
examination, a characteristic raised skin lesion of orange peel consistency known as shagreen 
patch is present in his lumbosacral region. Which one of the following is not seen in this 
autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome? 185 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Optic glioma is not seen in tuberous sclerosis. Tuberous sclerosis/Bourneville–Pringle Disease is 
an autosomal-dominant neurocutaneous syndrome, which may present during infancy with 
infantile spasms (as seen in the image), and has the characterisitic skin lesion known as shagreen 
patch. It is characterized by Vogt's triad (EPILOA), which includes • Epilepsy • Low intelligence (IQ) • Adenoma sebaceum The most common manifestations are skin lesions such as ashleaf (hypomelanotic) macules, 
adenoma sebaceum, shagreen patch, confetti lesions, and periungual fibromas. Koenen's tumours 
(periungual fibromas) are small fleshy tumors that grow under the toe nails/finger nails. Cortical tubers and subependymal nodules are the characteristic brain lesions. Other lesions 
include bilateral renal angiomyolipomas, facial angiofibroma, cardiac rhabdomyoma, and retinal 
hamartomas. Vigabatrin is the first-line therapy for infantile spasms in tuberous sclerosis. Note: Drug of choice for infantile spasms: adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) Image below: Adenoma sebaceum 200 
Sold by @itachibot Image below: Shagreen patch Image below: Periungual fibroma 201 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: The first child of a normal healthy couple was diagnosed to have cystic fibrosis. The parents 
are anxious and wish to seek advice for future pregnancies. What is the percentage of chances 
for the second child to be affected?
questions.explanation:
Cystic fibrosis follows autosomal recessive inheritance. Hence, the disease has a 25% chance of 
affecting the offspring. If parents are unaffected (both are carriers/heterozygotes): • 25% chance of normal genotype • 50% chance of carriers • 25% chance of homozygous In autosomal recessive disorders, the disease manifests itself when the offspring has a 
homozygous state, which means each child has a 25% chance of being affected by the disease. Note: There are 2 alleles for this, say for example "A" = normal allele and "a" = abnormal allele. So, if 
each parent is phenotypically normal and their child is affected, then they are carriers, i.e., "Aa". 
So, each parent has a 0.5 (50%) probability of passing the affected allele to the next generation. 
Also, having each child is an independent event, and the chance that the child receives an 
abnormal allele from the father (0.5), as well as a mother (0.5), is equal to 0.5 x 0.5 = 0.25 i.e. 
25%. 202 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: A 29-year-old woman is homozygous for an autosomal-recessive gene and her husband is 
heterozygous for the same. They are planning to start a family and wish to know the outcome 
of their pregnancy. Which out of the following options correctly represent the percentages of 
the outcome?

options.b: No child affected, but all are carriers

questions.explanation:
If the husband is heterozygous and the wife is homozygous for an autosomal recessive gene, 50% 
of the children will be affected; the rest will be carriers. This is pseudo-dominant inheritance, which refers to the observation of apparent dominant 
(parent to child) transmission of a known autosomal-recessive disorder, or it can also mean the 
inheritance of a recessive trait mimics a dominant pattern. This occurs when a homozygous affected individual has a partner who is a heterozygous carrier, 
and their children have a 1 in 2 chance to get affected (50%). 203 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 14: What is the mode of inheritance of Menke's disease?
questions.explanation:
The mode of inheritance of Menke's disease is X-linked recessive. X-linked recessive disorders have the following features: • Males are affected more commonly and more severely than females. • Female carriers have a 25% risk for having an affected son, a 25% risk for a carrier daughter, 
and a 50% chance of having a child that does not inherit the mutated X-linked gene. • The affected father will have all daughters (100%) to be carriers and unaffected sons because 
they pass their X chromosome to all of their daughters and their Y chromosome to all of their 
sons. X- linked recessive pattern of inheritance is shown in the image given below: Kinky hair disease (Menkes d

questions.question:
Question 15: A 41-year-old father of two has an X-linked genetic disorder. His daughter is a carrier for the 
same and his son is unaffected. His wife is healthy with no inherited disease. Which of the 
following is an example of this disorder?
questions.explanation:
204 
Sold by @itachibot The mode of inheritance is X- linked recessive and Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is an example of 
such a genetic disorder.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is an X-linked disorder?
questions.explanation:
Color blindness is primarily inherited as an X-linked recessive trait. The genes for color vision are 
located on the X chromosome. Males have a single X chromosome inherited from mothers. If the X chromosome inherited 
carries a mutation, males exhibit the disease. However, females become carriers of the color 
blindness gene and have a 50% chance of passing it on to their children. Female carriers usually are protected because of the random inactivation of one X chromosome. 
But there is a possibility that the mutant X chromosome remains active if the normal alleles are 
inactivated in some of the cells so the heterozygous female can express the disorder partially. The image shows the pattern of X-linked inheritance: In color blindness, the mechanism to appreciate one or more primary colors is either defective 
(anomalous) or absent (anopia). It may be congenital or acquired. Congenital color blindness can 
be dyschromatopsia (defective color vision of any one of the RGB colors) or achromatopsia 
(complete color blindness of all three RGB colors). RGB colors are red, green, and blue. Tests for color blindness include the Ishihara test, Hardy–Rand–Rittler test, and Farnsworth–
Munsell 100-hue test.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is not true regarding ataxia-telangiectasia?

options.b: Follows autosomal dominant mode of inheritance

questions.explanation:
Ataxia telangiectasia (AT) or Louis–Bar syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder. 205 
Sold by @itachibot The defect in AT is in the ATM gene localized to chromosome 11q22-23. The ATM gene is involved 
in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks. This defect in DNA repair leads to combined 
immunodeficiency (impaired immunoglobin isotype switching and association with thymic 
hypoplasia) and predisposition to an increased risk of lymphoreticular tumors such as lymphoma 
or leukemia. AT is characterized by progressive ataxia (beginning during infancy), telangiectasia (initially on 
bulbar conjunctiva), sinopulmonary infections, hypogonadism, sensitivity to ionizing radiation, 
insulin resistance, and raised alpha-fetoprotein levels.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 12-year-old boy presented with progressive muscular weakness showing the following 
finding. It was found that the child is unable to get up from a squatting position. He was 
diagnosed with a hereditary muscular disorder. What is the mode of inheritance in this 
disorder?
questions.explanation:
This clinical vignette includes an image of a child with pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles along 
with a history of inability to get up from a squatting position. This is characteristically seen in 
Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is an X-linked recessive disorder. Salient features of Duchenne muscular dystrophy: • Most common hereditary neuromuscular disease. • X-linked recessive mutations of dystrophin gene on chromosome Xp21. Clinical features: • Progressive weakness, developmental delay, and intellectual impairment • In toddlers: delayed walking, falling, toe walking, and trouble running or walking upstairs • Common sites of muscular hypertrophy: calf > tongue > forearm • Pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles due to fibrofatty replacement of muscle • Gower's sign: Patients use their arms and hands to walk up their own body from a squatting 
position due to the reduced strength in the proximal muscles(hip &thigh) of the lower limbs. • Trendelenburg gait/hip waddle • Inability to walk develops by the age of 10-14 years. • Complications: Contractures, scoliosis, cardiomyopathy, malignant hyperthermia after 
anaesthesia. • Death occurs by 3rd decade of life due to respiratory failure. Note: Becker's Muscular Dystrophy (BMD) vs. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) Mnemonic- • BMD: Badly makes dystrophin (defective) • DMD: Does not make dystrophin (absent) 206 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 19: Your second cousin, Prakriti, has been recently diagnosed with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. 
Your relatives are worried and keep calling you to confirm the new information that they read 
on the internet. In an attempt to settle their doubts about the credibility of online resources, 
you inform them that all of the following are true except:

options.a: X- linked recessive mode of inheritance
options.b: Atopic dermatitis and eczema during infancy

questions.explanation:
IgM is decreased in Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome, not increased. It is a rare genetic 
immunodeficiency that keeps a child's immune system from functioning properly. It also makes it 
difficult for a child's bone marrow to produce platelets, making a child prone to bleeding. This 
syndrome is associated with decreased IgM, increased IgA, and increased IgE levels. Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome: Mnemonic WAXTIE • WA: Wiskott–Aldrich • X: X-linked recessive • T: Thrombocytopenia • I: Infections • E: Eczema

questions.question:
Question 20: A 5-year-old girl has been diagnosed with a genetic disorder that follows a Mendelian pattern 
of inheritance illustrated by the pedigree chart below. Which of the following can be a likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given pedigree chart illustrates an inheritance pattern that is suggestive of an X-linked 
dominant disorder. Hence, hypophosphatemic rickets, which is an X-linked dominant disorder, is 
a likely diagnosis here. X- linked dominant disorders: • Females are affected twice as often as males. • An affected female has a 50% probability of transmitting the disorders to her son or daughter. • An affected male transmits the disorder to all of his daughters and none of his sons. 207 
Sold by @itachibot • Some X-linked dominant conditions are lethal in a high percentage of males, e.g., incontinentia 
pigmenti. Other options: • Lesh–Nyhan syndrome: X-linked recessive disorder affects young boys due to the deficiency of 
HGPRT enzyme in the purine pathway. It is marked by compulsive self-mutilation of the head and 
hands, together with learning difficulties and involuntary muscular movements. • Fabry disease: X-linked recessive lysosomal storage disease due to the deficiency 
of alpha-galactosidase A. Affected males have angiokeratomas, hypohidrosis, acroparesthesias, 
and corneal-lenticular opacities. Note: Mnemonic to remember X-linked dominant disorders: Ribbons For All Children • Ribbons - Rett’s syndrome/ Hypophosphatemic Rickets • For - Fragile X tremor/ataxia syndrome (FXTAS) • All - Alport syndrome • Children - Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease

questions.question:
Question 21: A 3-year-old girl presented with poor growth and social interaction as well as midline 
stereotypical movements of the hands as seen in the image below. All milestones were normal 
for the first 2 years. After that, the milestones delayed and her development slowed down. On 
examination, her gait was slightly clumsy, her speech had regressed to mere babbling and her 
anthropometry was below the 50th percentile. Following a battery of investigations, the 
diagnosis of a rare inherited disease was made. What is the affected gene for this condition? 189 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given features of poor growth & social interaction, gradual loss of speech, clumsy gait 
along with the characteristic hand movements point towards a likely diagnosis of Rett’s 
syndrome. The gene involved in Rett’s syndrome is the MeCP2 gene located on the X chromosome 
(Xq28 predominantly of paternal origin). Rett’s syndrome: • Almost always affects girls (X- linked dominant) • Development may proceed normally until 1 year of age slowing down to the extent of regression. • After 1 year of age, rapid regression in language and hand skills, motor milestones, and acquired 
microcephaly become apparent. • Clinical features can include repetitive hand wringing movements, ataxia, breathing dysfunction, 
bruxism, scoliosis, and profound mental retardation. • Autistic behaviour is a typical finding in all patients. Note: • Rb: Retinoblastoma: 13 chromosome • P53: Li–Fraumeni syndrome, Sarcomas: 17 • NF1: Neurofibromatosis 1-17 • NF2: Neurofibromatosis 2-22 • WT1: Wilms's tumour: 11 • FGFR3: Achondroplasia 208 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:

across the following list of examples and spot an error. Which of the following diseases will 
you mark for omission?
questions.explanation:
Hereditary motor-sensory neuropathy, commonly known as Charcot-Marie-Tooth neuropathy, is a 
type of X-linked dominant disorder. The rest of the options are associated with trinucleotide 
repeat sequences. Triple-repeat mutations (Allelic expansion disorders). • Due to an increase in the number of nucleotide repeats above a certain threshold. • Length of the nucleotide repeat often correlates with the severity of the disease. • Anticipation: When repeat length increases from one generation to the next, disease

questions.question:
Question 23: A 3-year-old child presents with previously diagnosed fragile X syndrome. As an intern posted 
in the department, you are asked to follow up on his cytogenetic analysis report. What is the 
trinucleotide repeat mutation seen in the report?
questions.explanation:
The trinucleotide repeat mutation associated with fragile X syndrome is CGG in the familial 
mental retardation -1 (FMR1) gene. Other common trinucleotide repeat mutations and their associated conditions: • GAA- Friedreich ataxia • CAG- Huntington disease • CTG- Myotonic dystrophy

questions.question:
Question 24: An 8-year-old boy was brought for psychiatric evaluation for intellectual disability. On 
examination, his IQ was 45 and a previous report in his records show a trinucleotide repeat 
mutation of CGG. Which of the following is not seen in it?
questions.explanation:
In fragile-X syndrome, there would be a small nose, not large. • Fragile X syndrome or Martin–Bell syndrome: Trinucleotide repeat mutation of CGG. 209 
Sold by @itachibot Remember mnemonic Hello Mr. FRAGILE X Syndrome: • Hello: Hyperextensible joint or high-arched palate • Mr: Mitral valve prolapse • F: FMR1 P deficiency (fragile X mental retardation 1 protein) - upregulates the metabotropic 
glutamate receptor (mGluR) 5 pathway and alters the expression of matrix metalloproteinase 
(MMP) 9. • R: Repeating the sequence of 3 nucleotides CGG, recurrent otitis media. • A: Autism/Attention deficit–hyperactivity disorder/Anxiety • G: Giant brain (macrocephaly) and giant testis (macroorchidism) • I: Intellectual disability, i.e., mental retardation • L: Long face with a large mandible • E: Everted ear • X: X-linked disorder (controversial as to whether it is X-linked dominant or recessive) The most common genetic cause of mental retardation is Down’s syndrome > Fragile X 
Syndrome. Sherman's paradox: Risk of expressing mental retardation in fragile X syndrome increases in later 
generations (anticipation). Fragile X-associated tremor or ataxia: Intention tremors and cerebellar ataxia, which may 
progress to parkinsonism. Note: Inhibitors of the mGluR (overexpressed in fragile X) are undergoing clinical trials. Minocycline 
(lowers MMP9) has resulted in short-term improvements in anxiety, mood, and the Clinical 
Global Impression Scale. Image: A child with affected fragile X- syndrome; note the everted ears, long face, and large 
mandible. 210 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 25: As a participant in the Indian Academy of Paediatrics quiz, you are asked to mark the type of 
inheritance in MELAS. The pedigree chart shown in the image below is provided to explain 
which family members may be affected (coloured in red). Which of the following will you 
choose?
questions.explanation:
The type of inheritance in MELAS is mitochondrial, which manifests as mitochondrial 
myopathy, encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes. Mitochondrial inheritance: • Inherited exclusively from the affected mother (ovum) as an individual’s mitochondrial genome 
is entirely derived from the mother because sperms contain few mitochondria, which are typically 
shed upon fertilization. • Both male and female children born to an affected mother will inherit the disease. • 80% of mitochondrial DNA codes for mitochondrial RNA, and therefore most mitochondrial 
DNA mutations lead to functional problems, which may be manifested as muscle disorders. The following pedigree shows the mitochondrial inheritance pattern-

questions.question:
Question 26: In order to understand the topic 'Non-Mendelian disorders', you have prepared flashcards. 
But, while browsing through them before your viva, the order of cards have been jumbled up. 
Which of the following option will you choose to correctly match the phenomena with their 
definitions?
questions.explanation:
The phenomena are correctly matched with their definitions as follows- • Genomic imprinting: Phenotypic expression of a gene depending on the parent of origin. • Mosaicism: Single organism possessing more than one genetic line as the result of genetic 
mutation. • Anticipation: Symptoms become more severe and/or appear at an earlier age as the disorder is 
passed from one generation to the next. • Non-penetrance: A genetic trait that is present in the genome but does not manifest itself in the 
individual. 211 
Sold by @itachibot Genomic imprinting: epigenetic process, that selectively inactivates either the maternal or 
paternal allele. These defects include: • Beckwith- Wiedemann syndrome • Silver Russell syndrome • Angelman syndrome • Prader Willi syndrome Note: Uniparental disomy: This refers to the situation in which two copies of a chromosome come from 
the same parent, instead of one from each parent. Eg., Angelman syndrome and Prader Willi
